Issues.Title: refactor(core): move TransferState implementation to core
Issues.Body:
This commit moves the `TransferState` class implementation to `@angular/core`. This class will be needed in core in followup changes and `core` can not depend on `platform-browser` package.

The `core` package does **not** export those symbols into public API surface. The `platform-browser` package re-exports the symbols under same names for backwards-compatibility.

## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [x] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(core): move TransferState implementation to core" (#49222)

Issues.Title: Add the localize package page is outdated
Issues.Body:
### Describe the problem that you experienced

> To add the @angular/localize package, use the following command to update the package.json and polyfills.ts files in your project.

On freshly created Angular 15 project, there is no polyfills.ts file. If you are using the "ng add @angular/localize" command, then I guess it does all the necessary steps. Though, the command did not add anything to polyfills, it just added types to "tsconfig.app.json" and "tsconfig.spec.json" file.

Another problem is that, if you want to migrate your existing Angular 14 project to Angular 15 and remove "polyfills.ts" file, there is no info, how I should add localize package to project. I tried to run "ng add @angular/localize"  but I just got message "Skipping installation: Package already installed. Nothing to be done." I tried to uninstall the package first and then add it, but that did no help. I guess it's because I have dependency that needs this package and has it already installed.

I tried to consult first page https://angular.io/api/localize but it also just says to use same command.

Issues.Title: perf(core): store producers and consumers in a linear array structure
Issues.Body:
This commit swaps out the `Map` storage for producers and consumers to use a
linear array as data structure, with keys being stored at even indices and
values at odd indices. The primary benefit of this data structure is that it
provides faster iteration.

Deleting elements inserts `null` values into both the key and value slots,
meaning that the array never shrinks in size. These empty slots are reused
when inserting new elements.

---

Based on top of #49216; only the fourth commit is new.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "perf(core): store producers and consumers in a linear array structure" (#49218)

Issues.Title: perf(core): prioritize checking the producer that marked a consumer as dirty
Issues.Body:
Each consumer that has been marked as stale has to verify if one of its
producers has actually changed in the pull phase of the reactivity algorithm.
This involves iterating over all producers to see if any of them reports an
actual value change.

This commit implements an optimization where the producer that marks a consumer
as dirty will be captured in the consumer, such that the consumer can
prioritize checking that particular producer. This is beneficial, since it is
a likely candidate to actually report a change.

---

Based on top of #49215; only the third commit is new.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "perf(core): prioritize checking the producer that marked a consumer as dirty" (#49216)

Issues.Title: perf(core): reduce effects queueing overhead
Issues.Body:
perf(core): reduce effects queueing overhead
This commit improves the performance of effect queuing and flushing by reducing
`Set` operations.

The work to queue an effect has been reduced by avoiding a `globalWatches`
lookup, in favor of reassigning the scheduling callback to a become a no-op.

Flushing the queue has been made more efficient by clearing all queued watches
at once, instead of individually per watched item. If an effect throws an error
then it will prevent the watch queue from being cleared at all, but the
internal dirty logic of `Watch` will prevent watches from executing multiple
times when the queue is flushed again.

---

Based on top of #49214; only the second commit is new.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "perf(core): reduce effects queueing overhead" (#49215)

Issues.Title: perf(core): lazily create promise needed to support `effectsDone`
Issues.Body:
The signals library used to eagerly create a promise to be able to notify when the effects queue had been flushed using `effectsDone()`. However, the creation of this promise is not without its cost (it shows up as significant cost in [js-reactivity-benchmark][1]), so this commit moves the creation to become lazy until `effectsDone()` has actually been called.

[1]: https://github.com/modderme123/js-reactivity-benchmark/
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "perf(core): lazily create promise needed to support `effectsDone`" (#49214)

Issues.Title: Unclear demonstration about viewProviders dealing with projected content
Issues.Body:
### Describe the problem that you experienced I am confused about the usage of the `viewProviders` when deal with `ng-content` situation. With the [doc](https://angular.io/guide/hierarchical-dependency-injection#providers-vs-viewproviders) said: > Since the dog üê∂ is declared inside the <#VIEW>, it isn't visible to the projected content. Instead, the projected content sees the whale üê≥. I am curious about whether üê≥ is still visible for `InspectorComponent` when `AnimalService` is provided as `viewProvieders` in `AppComponent`? And [here](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-rgv5yv?file=src%2Fapp%2Fcomponents%2Finspector.component.ts,src%2Fapp%2Fcomponents%2Fapp-child.component.ts,src%2Findex.html,src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.ts,src%2Fapp%2Fapp.module.ts) is my repo. The result is `InspectorComponent` which has been projected get the üê≥ from `AppComponent`'s `viewProvieders`. Is that reasonable? Cause i got nothing about this from the Doc. I aslo reproduce the mental model from my [repo](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-rgv5yv?file=src%2Fapp%2Fcomponents%2Finspector.component.ts,src%2Fapp%2Fcomponents%2Fapp-child.component.ts,src%2Findex.html,src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.ts,src%2Fapp%2Fapp.module.ts). > Since üê≥ is declared inside the <#VIEW>, it should be invisible to the projected content? ``` <#VIEW @Provide(AnimalService="üê≥")> <#VIEW @Provide(AnimalService="üê∂")>

Content projection

"üê≥">

Emoji from AnimalService: {{animal.emoji}} (üê≥)
<#VIEW>

Emoji from AnimalService: {{animal.emoji}} (üê∂)

 ``` After this, i read the [code](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/74258f3652eff268c7599c0f71baf929ed5b244b/packages/core/src/render3/di.ts#L529), `canAccessViewProviders` is false when DI process in `ChildComponent` while true in `AppComponent`. So, at least, the doc should say that `the dog üê∂ is only invisible to its own projected content` like this. It's really fuzzy to me to make a clear understanding. ### Enter the URL of the topic with the problem https://angular.io/guide/hierarchical-dependency-injection#providers-vs-viewproviders ### Describe what you were looking for in the documentation How `viewProviders` dealing with this projected content? ### Describe the actions that led you to experience the problem - There is a lack of clear definition and demos about how `viewProviders` worked with `ng-content` in different circumstances ### Describe what you want to experience that would fix the problem - Make a specific defination about how `viewProviders` dealing with projected content. - Supply more examples to demonstrate them in kinds of circumstances. - Make a specific answer about whether it is reasonable that the children projected content should access the parent `viewProviders`. ### Add a screenshot if that helps illustrate the problem _No response_ ### If this problem caused an exception or error, please paste it here ```true no ``` ### If the problem is browser-specific, please specify the device, OS, browser, and version _No response_ ### Provide any additional information here in as much as detail as you can _No response_

Issues.Title: fix(common): invalid ImageKit transformation
Issues.Body: `q-auto` is an invalid/unsupported transformation and should not be used ## PR Checklist Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements: - [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit - [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features) - [x] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features) ## PR Type What kind of change does this PR introduce? - [x] Bugfix - [ ] Feature - [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables) - [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes) - [ ] Build related changes - [ ] CI related changes - [ ] Documentation content changes - [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes - [ ] Other... Please describe: ## What is the current behavior? The `ImageLoader` for ImageKit is using an invalid/unsupported transformation (`q-auto`). Being that I could not find any mention of this transformation in [the official documentation](https://docs.imagekit.io/features/image-transformations/resize-crop-and-other-transformations#quality-q), I contacted ImageKit's support and they said: > q-auto while would result in different sizes because of some internal implementations, being an unsupported, undocumented feature, it should not be used in any application. Issue Number: N/A ## What is the new behavior? The `q-auto` invalid transformation is not used. Instead, we rely on the default quality value from ImageKit's dashboard, which unless modified is 80 (`q-80`). ## Does this PR introduce a breaking change? - [ ] Yes - [x] No ## Other information Unless modified (and if not overwritten via URL), ImageKit applies the following transformations: - Automatic format (`f-auto`) - Quality = 80 (`q-80`)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(common): invalid ImageKit transformation" (#49201)

Issues.Title: [FeatureRequest] Run TypeCheck with ngtsc just like you run tsc --noEmit
Issues.Body:
### Command

build, lint

### Description

We would like to create a pre-commit script that check for compiling errors in the changed files in our project.
We do this with `tsc --noEmit file.ts` today and it works well for `ts` errors. But it won't find `ngtsc` errors like this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5993909/221140302-f87edb63-1b2f-4bad-a6bc-7de918db8ccf.png)

Is it possible to do this today? I have tried the linter, but since it's not a syntax error it won't fail the linter.

### Describe the solution you'd like

It would be nice to be able to type-check specific files without doing a full build.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

We have already tried all solutions we could think of.

Issues.Title: Standalone migration fails in various cases
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

I've tried the new standalone migration inside one of our larger projects (managed by NX). By doing so, I've noticed the following issues:
- Barrel imports are not used. This results in _a lot_ of specific component/directive imports being added. 
- Typescript `paths` are not used. E.g. importing from a library into another one results in a relative import instead of `@my-org/lib`. This is probably a little tricky, since this is exactly what should happen from within the same library, so we don't end up with the library importing itself.
- The migration seems to break as soon as a library is added to the projects folder via `ng add` (so inside a non NX workspace)

I've created a repo reflecting all the mentioned issues above.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://github.com/TomTomB/ng-sa-migration-issues

```true
(none)
```

Issues.Title: There are inconsistent and confusing postcss/autoprefixer warnings from "styles" in angular.json
Issues.Body:
### Command

build, serve

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

When seeing postcss/autoprefixer warnings from `ng serve` or `ng build`, the output of the where the warning is happening is hard to parse through. Also, the warnings do not consistently show up in the logs.

Regression details:
I know the filenames for the postcss/autoprefixer warnings used to display differently, so I would say that's a regression. I'm not sure whether that's directly related to angular-cli or a package it happens to depend on. 

As far as the issue with the warnings not always getting logged, I'm not sure which version this behavior changed.

I know that the behavior of both of these issues was different in @angular/cli 11. 

### Minimal Reproduction

repo: https://github.com/rsc092020/autoprefixer-warnings-14.git

steps:

- `ng new autoprefixer-warnings-14`

- Add css file, and update angular.json to include css file in "styles" array.

- run `ng serve` or `ng build` 

- Observe autoprefixer warning:

```
./styles2.css.webpack[javascript/auto]!=!./node_modules/css-loader/dist/cjs.js??ruleSet[1].rules[5].rules[0].oneOf[0].use[1]!./node_modules/postcss-loader/dist/cjs.js??ruleSet[1].rules[5].rules[0].oneOf[0].use[2]!./styles2.css - Warning: Module Warning (from ./node_modules/postcss-loader/dist/cjs.js):
Warning

(5:3) autoprefixer: You should write display: flex by final spec instead of display: box
```

- run `ng serve` or `ng build` again
- Observe that the build completed and no autoprefixer warning

**It appears that i can clean the build cache to get the warning to show up again, but there are other warnings, like for commonjs dependencies, that will always show up. I don't understand why these warnings are different.**

### Exception or Error

_No response_

### Your Environment

```text
Angular CLI: 14.2.10
Node: 16.19.0
Package Manager: npm 8.19.3
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 14.2.12
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1402.10
@angular-devkit/build-angular   14.2.10
@angular-devkit/core            14.2.10
@angular-devkit/schematics      14.2.10
@angular/cli                    14.2.10
@schematics/angular             14.2.10
rxjs                            7.5.7
typescript                      4.7.4
```


### Anything else relevant?

_No response_

Issues.Title: feat(@schematics/angular): factor out logic from getRouterModuleDeclaration
Issues.Body:
Can now get module declarations of modules other than RouterModule. This is useful for adding a custom declaration to module using schematics. Checking the spec files will show a use case for this new feature, now the getModuleDeclarationByName function can be used to get the module declaration of a custom module, in this case ngxsModule.

Issues.Title: Angular CLI 15.1.4 breaks ng test with jsdom because CLI is loading JavaScript bundles as module
Issues.Body:
### Command

test

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

15.1.3

### Description

I have a standard Angular project, using Karma & Jasmine for unit tests. The unit tests run can run in either Chrome or jsdom. I need jsdom because my CI environment doesn't have Chrome (org policy: no browsers on servers).

Angular CLI 15.1.4 introduced a change in https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/24620 wherein Javascript bundles are loaded as modules. 

Unfortunately, jsdom doesn't support <script type="module">; it simply doesn't load the module scripts. This is a known issue in jsdom - https://github.com/jsdom/jsdom/issues/2475

Ideally jsdom would add module support; but since that ticket has been open for four years, I'm not holding out much hope. So instead, here's my request:

**REQUEST:** Could Angular CLI add a flag to add/omit type="module" ?

My workaround for now is patching jsdom (using patch-package) to ignore the type attribute on <script type="module">.

### Minimal Reproduction

Clone my git repo: https://github.com/andrewpmontgomery/angular-15-jsdom
1. Run `npm install`
2. Run `npm run test:chrome` and all three tests should pass.
3. Run `npm run test:jsdom` and it should time-out.
4. Run `npm run patch-package`
5. Run `npm run test:jsdom` again and now it works.


### Exception or Error

_No response_

### Your Environment

```text
Angular CLI: 15.2.0
Node: 16.19.1
Package Manager: npm 8.19.3
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 15.2.0
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router
```

Issues.Title: Improve Hot Module Replacement (HMR)
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Description

Angular CLI currently supports HMR via `ng serve --hmr` though it isn't the ideal experience. Under the hood, this mostly rerenders the Angular application from scratch, which is better than a full page reload, but could definitely be improved. @alan-agius4 has suggested a number of opportunities for improving HMR. Most importantly, our strategy here should be to optimize the turnaround time for any given change _scaled_ with the frequency of that kind of change. For example, it is very common to make numerous tiny adjustments to CSS in quick succession while finding the precise styling needed for a page. This is a very hot path to optimize and even marginal improvements here can have a bit impact due to how frequently CSS-only changes are made during development.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Some ideas to improve HMR include (but are not limited to):

* Fast track CSS-only changes and apply them to any existing components on the page.
    * This should be relatively straightforward since we mostly need to correlate a component class with its `<style />` tag on the page, then delete and recreate that tag with the new CSS content. This would be very fast and maintain page state.
    * Supporting inline styles is a bit more complicated but should be achievable?
* Fast track Angular template-only changes and apply them to any existing components on the page.
    * In theory, we just need to delete the generated JavaScript render functions for a component and overwrite them with the new render functions from the modified template, then re-apply the DOM.
    * In practice, I think this is a challenge as Angular templates aren't completely stateless (ex. `async` pipe). But this is likely achievable in some capacity. Should be pretty quick and mostly maintain page state.
    * Supporting inline templates is a bit more complicated but should be achievable?
* Re-render only the currently displayed Angular route, rather than the full application.
    * Statistically speaking, most code changes will be within the currently displayed Angular route and won't impact anything outside the route. In many cases, it would be sufficient to just rerender that one route.

Angular template and CSS changes in particular are two areas where users frequently make a large number of small changes in quick succession and in a manner which is easy for tooling to reason about. These are two spaces where we can have a huge impact on developer's quality of life.

If we can get this good enough, I'd love to get to a place where we could turn `--hmr` on by default in `ng serve`.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

HMR is mostly one facet of the larger problem around "How do we make the time between editing a file and reloading its changes in the browser as quick as possible?" (edit/refresh time). HMR is one means of getting built changes into the running browser faster and maintain the application's current state. We should (and are) investigating ways to improve the overall edit/refresh experience independent of HMR.

More related to HMR, the focus on Angular template and CSS changes does highlight a lack of focus on TypeScript changes. This is somewhat intentional. Angular has strong separation of concerns between Angular templates (for HTML/DOM rendering), CSS (for styling), and TypeScript (for component functionality). While this isn't absolute and TypeScript can often containing rendering or styling functionality (ex. list filters or conditional CSS classes), the vast majority of DOM and CSS changes made by a developer will be done by editing a template or a stylesheet, not TypeScript.

TypeScript changes are also very tricky to apply consistently with HMR. As one example, renaming a class field in TypeScript _can_ be HMR'd, however doing so often leads to inconsistencies and confusing behavior. HMR is intended to maintain the current user state, but it is effectively impossible for the build process to understand that deleting a `foo` field and creating a `bar` field as intended as a rename and state should be transferred from one property to the other during HMR. At runtime, it looks like this renamed field just "forgot" all its state, which can easily break the component and cause errors which require a full page reload to fix. That's one example, but the sheer variety of possible changes a user can make to TypeScript code means it can never be totally consistent or reliable.

We should definitely be open to improvements here where we can take advantage of them, and we should make sure not to let "perfect" be the enemy of "good enough". The key takeaway here is that HMR of TypeScript-only changes in Angular is simultaneously the hardest to do right, and also the least impactful. Again, _scaling_ the impact of optimizing a particular change with the _frequency_ that kind of change occurs is where we can find the most value for users.

/cc @alan-agius4 for other ideas around improving HMR, definitely lots of cool stuff we're hoping to do here.

Issues.Title: help(map-directions-renderer):  Can't display multiple routes
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

hi real beginner here with this but i'm trying to display all the routes on the maps using the below as per the documentation within the html:
`<map-directions-renderer *ngIf="(dResultTransit | async) as directionsResults1" [directions]="directionsResults1"></map-directions-renderer>`

i have the request to provide route alternatives:
`    let request: google.maps.DirectionsRequest = {
      origin: this.origin,
      destination: this.destination,
      travelMode: google.maps.TravelMode.TRANSIT,
      provideRouteAlternatives: true,
      transitOptions: {
        modes: transitMode,
        routingPreference: this.transitPreference
      },
    }
`

this is followed with providing the dResultTransit as defined:
`  dResultTransit: Observable<google.maps.DirectionsResult | undefined> | undefined;`

`this.dResultTransit = this.DirectionsServiceTransit.route(this.TransitRequest()).pipe(map(response => response.result));`






### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1.  I tried different travel modes and turning off the provide route alternatives to ensure the displaying of the routes is correct
2. I tried using different machines and os and i am getting the same result

### Expected Behavior

I expect 4 routes to be displayed as per below
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/81580209/221355667-1dff1430-6797-40f9-8cac-227ae42abb1c.png)


### Actual Behavior

however, this is only currently displaying 1 route.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/81580209/221355705-032cd3fe-0397-4625-878d-79b6477631bf.png)




### Environment

- Angular: 15.0.5
- CDK/Material: 15.1.4
- Browser(s): Google Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS and Windows

Issues.Title: bug(mat-chip): ngIf on matChipRemove breaks style
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Hi,
When using the `mat-chip` with a button that has the `matChipRemove` directive combined with the `*ngIf` structural directive, as the condition changes from true / false, the `mat-chip` does not seem to correctly handle the state change in it's css styling.



### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. add a mat-chip in your template

2. add a button with an `matChipRemove` directive and an `*ngIf` directive that resolves a condition
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8459019/221306084-d0d6f30f-0901-4f61-b033-93cc376dd209.png)

3. change the condition value so the button is removed/added to the DOM

Issues.Title: bug(mat-stepper): MatStepper and MatStep not working through content projection
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Hello. I'm not sure if this is by design, but I'd expect this code to work. MatStepper is already using `descendants: true` in it's `@ContentChildren` query so I'd assume this is allowed.

```ts
import 'zone.js/dist/zone';
import { Component } from '@angular/core';
import { CommonModule } from '@angular/common';
import { bootstrapApplication } from '@angular/platform-browser';
import { MatStepperModule } from '@angular/material/stepper';

@Component({
  selector: 'my-app-stepper-container',
  standalone: true,
  imports: [MatStepperModule],
  template: `
  <mat-stepper>
    <ng-content></ng-content>
  </mat-stepper>
  `
})
export class StepperContainer {}

@Component({
  selector: 'my-app',
  standalone: true,
  imports: [CommonModule, MatStepperModule, StepperContainer],
  template: `
    <my-app-stepper-container>
      <mat-step>my step</mat-step>
    </my-app-stepper-container>
  `,
})
export class App {
  name = 'Angular';
}

bootstrapApplication(App);
```
```
ERROR
Error: R3InjectorError(Standalone[App])[MatStepper -> MatStepper -> MatStepper]:
NullInjectorError: No provider for MatStepper!
```

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-tnkyk1?devToolsHeight=33&file=src/main.ts

### Expected Behavior

`MatStepper` and `MatStep` work through content projection.

### Actual Behavior

`NullInjectorError` is thrown.

### Environment

- Angular: 15.2.0
- CDK/Material: 15.2.0
- Browser(s): Chrome 110.0.5481.177 (Official Build) (x86_64)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-stepper): MatStepper and MatStep not working through content projection" (#26690)

Issues.Title: bug(component): No documentation for style overriding
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

I have a styling library which styles all material components based on a given desing specs.  But material v15 has migrated all angular components styles to [MDC components](https://github.com/material-components/material-components-web) which broke all our extisting styles because of DOM structure change.

Now we are again planning to styles all MDC components but this time we want to follow future proof styling path but I don't see any document which I can follow and add extensive styles on top of MDC styles.

I can see material now using `--mdc-*` custom properties for all components and using those variables I can override the styles but I don't see any documentation for the same.

Angular material now using [MDC](https://m2.material.io/components/) styles but MDC suggesting [Material Design 3](https://github.com/material-components/material-web) which is yet another web component library based on Lit.

Does Angular material continue using [MDC](https://m2.material.io/components/) components styles or planning to use  [Material Design 3](https://github.com/material-components/material-web) styles. 

What should be the best path for such users who want to override styles on top of Angular material library.

### Reproduction

NA

### Expected Behavior

There should be a proper documentation for style overriding 

### Actual Behavior

NA

### Environment

- Angular:
- CDK/Material:
- Browser(s):
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):

Issues.Title: bug(google-maps): google.maps.ControlPosition.RIGHT_TOP returning undefined when pushing measure distance widget
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

We are running some unit tests for our google map component where the tests seem to fail due to `google.maps.ControlPosition.RIGHT_TOP` returning undefined when trying to push the measure distance widget element in our `ngAfterViewInit()` function like so: `this.map.controls[google.maps.ControlPosition.RIGHT_TOP].push(measureDistanceWidgetRootElement)`

where `measureDistanceWidgetRootElement` is defined as a native element:
`this.measureDistanceWidget.map = this.map.googleMap!`
`let measureDistanceWidgetRootElement = this.measureDistanceWidget.element.nativeElement`

Error output:
`TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'push')`

However, all the tests pass once we change the control position to a value that does not return undefined, like `google.maps.ControlPosition.RIGHT_BOTTOM`. This behavior is only observed when running the unit tests and not while the application is running, the measure distance widget works as expected. Therefore, we want to know why some control positions are returning undefined while others are not and if this error could be replicated.

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:

Create a measure distance widget component and try pushing it to the RIGHT_TOP control position in ngAfterViewInit() as a native element, something like this:

`this.measureDistanceWidget.map = this.map.googleMap!
let measureDistanceWidgetRootElement = this.measureDistanceWidget.element.nativeElement
this.map.controls[google.maps.ControlPosition.RIGHT_TOP].push(
            measureDistanceWidgetRootElement
        )`

### Expected Behavior

`google.maps.ControlPosition.RIGHT_TOP` should not return undefined and the unit tests pass.

### Actual Behavior

`google.maps.ControlPosition.RIGHT_TOP` returns undefined and the unit tests fail.`

### Environment

- Angular CLI: 13.3.10
- Node: 16.14.0
- Package Manager: npm 8.3.1
- Browser(s): Google Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 64 bit

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1303.10
@angular-devkit/build-angular   13.3.10
@angular-devkit/core            13.3.10
@angular-devkit/schematics      13.3.10
@angular/cdk                    13.3.9
@angular/cli                    13.3.10
@angular/flex-layout            13.0.0-beta.38
@angular/google-maps            13.3.9
@angular/material               13.3.9
@schematics/angular             13.3.10
rxjs                            7.8.0
typescript                      4.6.4
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(google-maps): google.maps.ControlPosition.RIGHT_TOP returning undefined when pushing measure distance widget" (#26682)

Issues.Title: bug(cdk-menu): cdkMenuTriggerFor within cdkContextMenuTriggerFor causes repositioning when hovered
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Using a `[cdkMenuTriggerFor]` within a container that has a `[cdkContextMenuTriggerFor]` for the same cdkMenu.

Current behavior:
 When a cdkMenu is opened by the `[cdkContextMenuTriggerFor]` the cdkMenu it will be repositioned to the `[cdkMenuTriggerFor]` when the `[cdkMenuTriggerFor]` is hovered.

Expected behavior:
the cdkMenu should stay at its current location, even if `[cdkMenuTriggerFor]` is hovered.

In case this is confirmed as a bug, I could provide a PR fixing the issue

### Reproduction

Stackblitz: https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-uo4741?file=src/app/example-component.html

Steps to reproduce:
1. Right click on Lucas ipsum
2. hover Open Context Menu button


### Expected Behavior

contextMenu does not change position

### Actual Behavior

contextMenu moves to the location of the button trigger

### Environment

- Angular: 15
- CDK/Material: 15
- Browser(s): Firefox, Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Ubuntu

Can also be reproduced with the dev-app in the components repo

Issues.Title: fix(material/core): mat-option sets aria-selected="false"
Issues.Body:
For mat-option, set `aria-selected="false"` on deselected options. Confirms with [WAI ARIA Listbox authoring practices guide](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/listbox/), which says to always include aria-selected attribute on listbox options that can be selected. Fix issue where VoiceOver reads every option as "selected" (21491).

Fix #21491
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/core): mat-option sets aria-selected="false"" (#26673)
